newsitem.title: USA: Shell, Mobil crude output in U.S. Gulf still out.
newsitem.headline: Shell, Mobil crude output in U.S. Gulf still out.

text.p: Shell Oil and Mobil said late Tuesday crude oil output in the U.S. Gulf had not been fully restored since being shut down.
Production was reduced over the weekend as a precaution against Josephine, the tropical storm that moved through the Gulf of Mexico, making landfall in Florida last night.
Shell operates the Mars platform where 25,000 barrels per day (bpd) of sour crude was shut-in.
"Mars is not back in production. The workers will be doing some minor repairs before bringing it back up," a Shell company spokeswoman said.
She added she was not sure when capacity would be fully restored and did not disclose the nature of the repairs.
Separately, some portion of Mobil's 20,000 bpd of gross crude output has not returned to normal flows, with natural gas production still completely out.
"Some crude production has been brought back, but no gas production yet," said Chris Springham, spokesman for Mobil, adding that damage assessment was being carried out.
Mobil's field has a capacity of about 30 million cubic feet per day (mmcfd) of gas.
